# Lecture # 2 – Semiconductor Diodes

# Objectives:

Develop a working knowledge of the diode in  a variety of configurations using models appropriate for the  area of application\.

Sketch a PN junction under zero bias and show the depletion zones indicating the  relative charges of each area\.

Explain what happens to majority and minority carriers present in the different parts of  the diode\.

Explain Biasing Voltage \(Forward and Reverse\)

Show what happens to the depletion zone\, majority and minority carriers in the  presence of forward and reverse biasing voltages\.

Explain the process as a self regulated system

# Diodes

The diode is a 2\-terminal device\.

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_1.png)

A diode ideally conducts in  only one direction\.

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_2.png)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#c00000"> __Semiconductor Resistance:__ </span>

Intrinsic semiconductor  <span style="color:#336600">\(not</span>  <span style="color:#336600"> </span>  <span style="color:#336600">doped\)</span>  <span style="color:#001f5f">: </span>  <span style="color:#001f5f"> </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">high </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">resistance </span> \(since very  few free electrons or holes\)\.

N\-type semiconductor \(doped with donors\): <span style="color:#001f5f"> </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">low </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">resistance </span> \(due to  lots of free electrons\)\.

P\-type semiconductor  <span style="color:#336600">\(doped</span>  <span style="color:#336600"> </span>  <span style="color:#336600">with</span>  <span style="color:#336600"> </span>  <span style="color:#336600">acceptors\): </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">low </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">resistance</span>  <span style="color:#006fc0"> </span> \(due  to lots of holes\)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#c00000"> __Semiconductor Materials:__ </span>

Materials commonly used in the development of  semiconductor devices:

<span style="color:#336600">Silicon</span>  <span style="color:#336600"> </span>  <span style="color:#336600">\(Si\)</span>

<span style="color:#336600">Germanium</span>  <span style="color:#336600"> </span>  <span style="color:#336600">\(Ge\)</span>

<span style="color:#336600">G</span>  <span style="color:#336600">a</span>  <span style="color:#336600">lli</span>  <span style="color:#336600">um</span>  <span style="color:#336600"> </span>  <span style="color:#336600">A</span>  <span style="color:#336600">r</span>  <span style="color:#336600">s</span>  <span style="color:#336600">e</span>  <span style="color:#336600">n</span>  <span style="color:#336600">i</span>  <span style="color:#336600">de</span>  <span style="color:#336600"> </span>  <span style="color:#336600">\(G</span>  <span style="color:#336600">aA</span>  <span style="color:#336600">s\)</span>

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

One end of a silicon or germanium crystal can be doped as a  _p_ \-  type material and the other end as an  _n_ \-type material\.

The result is a  <span style="color:#cc3200"> _p\-n_ </span>  <span style="color:#cc3200"> _ _ </span>  <span style="color:#cc3200">junction</span> \.

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_3.png)

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_4.png)

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_5.png)

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_6.jpg)

It turns out that doing this makes a  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _diode _ </span> – a device with very useful characteristics\.

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

Some  of the free electrons from the n\-type  material flow into p\-type material\.

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_7.png)

Creating an area near the junction where the free electrons  have left the n\-type material\, and the holes are filled in the p\-type  material\.

This is called the <span style="color:#006fc0"> </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _depletion_ </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _ _ </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _region_ </span> \.

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_8.png)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_9.jpg)

If we consider the resistance of the p\-n junction\, we see that the  depletion region has  <span style="color:#3333ff"> _very high _ </span>  <span style="color:#3333ff"> _resistance_ </span>  <span style="color:#3333ff">\. </span>

<span style="color:#ff0000">Why</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">?</span>

Because the depletion  region is just like an intrinsic semiconductor with no extra free  electrons and holes due to doping\.

There exists a potential difference across the depletion layer and is called  <span style="color:#ff0000">barrier potential</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">\(V</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">0</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">\)</span> \.

The typical barrier potential is approximately:

<span style="color:#3333ff">For silicon\, V</span>  <span style="color:#3333ff">0</span>  <span style="color:#3333ff"> = 0\.7 V </span>

<span style="color:#3333ff">For germanium\, </span>  <span style="color:#3333ff">V</span>  <span style="color:#3333ff">0 </span>  <span style="color:#3333ff">= 0\.3</span>  <span style="color:#3333ff"> </span>  <span style="color:#3333ff">V</span>

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#c00000"> __Diode Operating Conditions:__ </span>

A diode has three operating conditions:

<span style="color:#0000ff">No</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">bias</span>

<span style="color:#0000ff">Reverse</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">bias</span>

<span style="color:#0000ff">Forward</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">bias</span>

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_10.png)

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_11.jpg)

<span style="color:#ff0000">No</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">Bias</span>

No external voltage is applied:  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _V_ </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _D_ </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _ _ </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">=</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">0</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">V</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">               </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _I_ </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _D_ </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _ _ </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">=</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">0</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">A</span>

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#c00000"> __Diode Operating Conditions:__ </span>

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_12.png)

The reverse voltage causes the  depletion region to widen\.

The electrons in the  _n_ \-type material  are attracted toward the positive  terminal of the voltage source\.

The holes in the  _p_ \-type material are  attracted toward the negative  terminal of the voltage source\.

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_13.png)

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_14.jpg)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#c00000"> __Diode Operating Conditions:__ </span>

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_15.png)

External voltage is applied across the  _p\-n _ junction in  the same polarity as the  _p_ \- and  _n_ \-type materials\.

The forward voltage causes the  depletion region to narrow\.

The electrons and holes are pushed  toward the  _p\-n_  _ _ junction\.

The electrons and holes have  sufficient energy to cross the  _p\-n _  _ _ junction\.

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_16.jpg)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#c00000"> __Practical Diode Characteristics:__ </span>

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_21.jpg)

Actual real diode is not perfect\.

<span style="color:#ff0000">It has </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">a very </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">small </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">current through </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">it </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">when  reverse</span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> biased\.</span>

And it has a small voltage across it when it is forward  biased\.

<span style="color:#3333ff">0\.7 V for Si</span>

<span style="color:#3333ff">0\.3 V for Ge</span>

<span style="color:#3333ff">1\.2 V GaAs</span>

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#c00000"> __Reverse Breakdown characteristics of a Diode__ </span>

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_22.jpg)

If we apply excess voltage on a real diode in  <span style="color:#ff0000">the </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">reverse </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">direction</span> \, the  diode will be  <span style="color:#ff0000">destroyed </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">and will </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">let </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">current </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">flow </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">in the </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">reverse </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">direction\.  </span>

This is called the  <span style="color:#336600">breakdown</span>  <span style="color:#336600"> </span>  <span style="color:#336600">voltage</span> \.

::: {.notes}

<span style="color:#339933"> __Light\-Emitting Diode __ </span>  <span style="color:#339933"> __\(LED\)__ </span>

An LED emits photons when it is forward biased\.

The color of light emitted by the diode is determined by the type  of material used in doping\.

The forward bias voltage is usually in the range of 2 V to 3 V\.

![](l2-diode-img/l2-diode_24.jpg)
